alert.note: Alert for Delaware; Randolph (Indiana) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued February 17 at 12:26PM EST until February 19 at 4:30PM EST by NWS Indianapolis
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Indiana... Illinois... Wabash River, Tippecanoe River, Wildcat Creek, and Mississinewa River. .Snow melt and rainfall from Wednesday night through today of around an inch and a half to over two and a half inches on frozen or saturated ground is bringing widespread flooding to central Indiana rivers. Moderate to major flooding is expected on the Mississinewa at Ridgeville. Moderate flooding is expected along upper parts of the Wabash from Lafayette through Covington as well as Wildcat Creek, while lowland and minor flooding is currently forecast for the Tippecanoe and the lower Wabash. Another system early next week could lengthen the amount of time in flood and produce additional rises on area rivers. ...FLOOD WARNING FOR SNOWMELT NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL SATURDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Mississinewa River near Ridgeville. * WHEN...Until Saturday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 16.3 feet, Record flooding in progress as flood waters overflow both banks and likely flood the approaches to CR 100 W bridge. Portions of SR 28 between Ridgeville and Deerfield are flooded. State Road 1 south of SR 28 and local river roads are flooded by more than two feet of water. The river may be one-half of a mile wide. Residential flooding in Ridgeville, Albany and Eaton. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 AM EST Thursday the stage was 12.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:00 AM EST Thursday was 12.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 16.5 tonight. It will then fall below flood stage late Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/ind. The next statement should be issued by late this evening.
